3.51: And what's the difference by the second day that he takes it? That when Torah hints, it hints by the second day, therefore we mention [rain] by the second day.
3.39: On the first Yom Tov of Pesach the first one mentions, on the last one doesn't mention."
3.38: "Someone who goes in front of the box [the Chazan],  on the last day of Yom Tov, the last [Chazan of Musof] mentions [rain], and the first [Chazan of Shachris] doesn't mention [rain].
3.11: Just as Lulav is by day, so too mentioning [rain] is by day,
3.13: Just as the pouring of the water is by night, as the master says "And their Karbon Mincha and their libations' is even at night" so too mentioning [rain] can be at night.
3.12: Or maybe from the pouring of the water?
3.15: "ר' אליעזר doesn't learn except from lulav."
3.14: Come and listen as רבי אבהו said,
3.17: "ר' אבהו learnt this from a tradition". And there those who say,
3.30: Therefore, if he wants to mention all year round, he can mention it.
3.37: ר' יהודה said in the name of  ר' יהושע said,
3.36: "On the 6th day of Yom Tov he mentions"
3.34: "On the second day of Yom Tov he mentions."
3.55: He holds like ר' יהודה בן בתירה as he says,
3.32: "I say from the time one STOPS asking [for rain] so too one should STOP mentioning [rain]."
3.50: From here is a hint for the pouring of the water from the תורה.

2.24: And since it was taught "And on Succot, we are judged about water" [therefore] it was taught When is the time, one should begin to mention “the Power of rains?”
2.25: And let it teach "When is the time, one should begin to mention rain?", what is "the Power of Rain".
2.27: Because it comes down with strength, as it says, "He makes great things, beyond comprehension, and wonders beyond number." And it is written, "He gives rain on the face of the land, and sends water on the face of the outskirts."
2.20: Then teach it over there, why did he leave it until here?
2.22: The Tanna is leaving [A Mishna in Meschtas] Rosh Hashana, as we learnt [there],
2.23: "And on Succot, we are judged about water".
2.40: The key of childbirth from where do we know? As it is written "And G-D remembered Rochel and listened
2.0: Mishnah: When is the time, one should begin to mention “the Power of rains?”
2.2: from the first day of the holiday
2.4: From the last day of the holiday
2.6: Since the rain on Succot is a sign of curse, why should it be mentioned in the prayers?
2.9: He said {Rabbi Yehushua to Rabbi Eliezer}
2.8: Never did I say that one must pray for the rain, but only that it should be mentioned in the following words, "He causes the winds to blow, and the rain to fall in the proper season."
2.39: The key of rains, as it is written "Hashem will open for you His good storehouse, the heaven, to give rain for your land in proper time."
2.38: The key of rains, the key of childbirth, the key of revival of the dead.
2.11: We don't ask for the rains, except close to (the time of) rains.
2.10: Then should this mention not be said throughout the year?
2.13: One who goes in front of the box (i.e. the chazan), on the last day of the holiday of Succos, the last one (chazan for Musaf) mentions, and the first one (chazan for Shachris) doesn't.
2.15: What is the Tanna referring to, when he asks "From when".
2.14: On the first day of the holiday of Pesach, the first one mentions, the last one doesn't mention.
2.17: We mention the power of rain in [the Blessing of] Techiyas Hamesiem, and we ask [for rain] in the Blessing of the Years, and Havdalah in [the Blessing of] Chonain Hadas.
2.16: The Tanna refers  [to that Mishnah] which says.
2.19: When is the time, one should begin to mention “the Power of rains?”.
2.31: It is written over here, ''He makes great things, beyond comprehension'', and it is written over there, "Do you not know, have you not heard, the G-d of the world, Hashem, the creator of the ends of Earth, does not weary, or become tired, His wisdom is beyond comprehension." and it is written, "Who sets mountains with His strength, who is girded with power."
2.30: It comes out from the two words "Comprehension" from the creation of the world.
2.37: [There are] Three keys in the hand of the Holy One, Blessed is He, that are not given over in the hand of a messenger, and these are them:
2.35: And it is written afterwards, "and I will give rain for your land in the proper time, the early, and the late rains."
2.34: "To love Hashem your G-D, and to serve Him with all your heart" what's the service that is done with the heart? You must say davening.
2.33: Since we learnt in a Baraisa
2.32: And from where do we know [that one should ask for rain] in Davening?

4.0: If [Rabbi Akiva] holds like Rabbi Yehuda ben Beseira, then let him say like his (Rabbi Yehuda ben Beseira's) opinion (that the water libations begin on the second day)!
4.3: It was taught (in a Baraisa): Rabbi Nasan says:
4.2: [that] when the additional water libation is written, it is written by the sixth day.
4.5: One of them a water libation, and one of them a wine libation.
4.7: If so, let the verse write either "hasech hesech" or "nesech
4.6: Say that they are both of wine!

9.48: If I say to you, that your fruit may be sweet, behold, your fruit (already) are sweet. That your shade will be pleasant, behold, your shade (already) is pleasant. That a stream of water should pass beneath you, behold, a stream of water (already does) flow beneath you.
9.25: ...Rav Nachman and Rabbi Isaac were sitting at a meal. Rav Nachman said to Rabbi Isaac
9.27: ...He [Rabbi Isaac] said to him, "So said Rabbi Yochanan"
9.46: And when he sought to go, he said,
9.47: "Tree, tree, with what shall I bless you?
9.44: "I will tell you a parable. To what is this similar? To a man who was walking in the desert and was hungry and tired and thirsty and found a tree whose fruit were sweet and whose shade was pleasant and which had water passing below it.
9.45: He ate of its fruit and drank of its waters and sat in its shade.
9.28: ...'One should not speak at a meal lest the windpipe go before the gullet and one's life will be endangered.'
9.29: ...After the meal, he [Rabbi Isaac] said to him,
9.41: When they were departing from each other, he said to him,
9.0: ...R. Nachman said to R. Yitzchak, What is the meaning of the verse, And it came to pass when Samuel was old. Did Samuel become old? He lived only for fifty-two years. As it was said, If a man dies at age 52 he is said to have died at the age reached by Shmuel, the Ramati? [R. Yitzchak] said,  R. Yochanan said, Old age jumped upon him, as it is written, I regret that I made Shaul King. [Shmuel] said, Lord of the World, You have equated me with Moshe and Aharon, as it is said  Moshe and Aharon are among God’s priests, and Shmuel among those who call in God’s name. Just as with Moshe and Aharon, their handiwork was not canceled in their time, so too let my handiwork not be canceled in my lifetime. God said, How shall I act? Should Shaul die? Shmuel will not allow it. Should Shmuel die young? People will cast aspersions on him. Should neither Shmuel nor Shaul die? The time has come for David to reign and one kingship may not encroach on another even by a hair's breadth. God said: I will cause old age to jump on [Shmuel].
9.31: ...Our forefather Jacob did not die. He said to him:
9.34: ...I expound a verse as it is written (Jeremiah 30:10) "Do not fear, my servant Jacob, said Adonai, and do not be dismayed O Israel. For I will save you from afar and your seed from
9.32: ...Was it for not that he was eulogized, embalmed and buried?
9.50: That it will be (God's) will that all of the plants which are planted from you

8.48: And is there a Jerusalem above?
8.49: Yes, it is written “The built-up Jerusalem is like a city that was joined together within itself.” (Psalms 122:3)
8.46: He replied, this is what R’ Yochanan said:
8.47: The Holy One said ‘I will not enter Jerusalem above until I can enter Jerusalem below.
8.44: R’ Nachman said to R’ Yitzchak:
8.45: What does this verse mean? “In your midst is the Holy One, and I will not enter a city.” (Hoshea 11:9) Because the Holy One is in your midst, I will not enter a city?!
8.9: Mishnah: Until when does one pray for the rains?
8.11: Until the Pesach passes.  Rabbi Meir says:
8.12: Until the end of Nissan, as is said (Joel 2:23), "and the rain shall fall for you, the early rains and the late rains, in the first".

39.25: ‘He did such and such to me.'
39.27: ‘Nevertheless, forgive him, for he is a man of great Torah learning.’
39.21: ‘If this man is a Rabbi, may there not be any more like him in Israel’!
39.29: ‘For your sakes I will forgive him,
39.0: A particularly ugly man happened upon him
39.3: and he [R. Eleazar) did not respond.
39.5: Good for nothing! How ugly this man is!
39.6: Are all the people of your city as ugly as you are?
39.9: When he [R. Eleazar] acknowledged, in his gut, that he had done wrong he got down from his donkey and prostrated himself before the man and said to him,
39.8: I do not know, but go and tell the artisan who made me, how ugly is the vessel which you have made.
39.10: I submit myself to you; forgive me.
39.13: He [R. Eleazar] walked behind him until he reached his city.
39.12: I will not forgive you until you go to the artisan that created me and tell him: How ugly is the vessel that you created.
39.15: ‘Peace be upon you Rabbi and teacher,’
39.14: When his fellow citizens came out to meet him greeting him with the words,
39.19: ‘The man who is walking behind you.’
39.31: Immediately, R. Eleazar son of R. Simeon entered [the Beit Midrash] and expounded,
39.30: but only if he does not make a habit of acting this way.’
39.32: A man should always be soft like a reed and not hard like a cedar. And for this reason the reed merited that of it should be made a quill for the writing of the Torah scroll, phylacteries and mezuzot.

38.54: A person should always be soft like a reed and not hard like a cedar.
38.49: Achiyah the Shilonite cursed [Israel] as a reed. He said to Israel, "ADONAI will strike down Israel as the wavering reed,"(1 Kgs, 14:15) for as the reed stands in a watery place, sprouts shoots, and has abundant roots, so even if all the winds in the world come and blow against it, it will not shift from its place, but rather it will sway to and fro with them.
38.55: It once happened that R. Eleazar the son of R. Simeon was coming from Migdal Gedor, from the house of his teacher, and he was riding his donkey by the river and he felt a great happiness and full of himself because he had studied a lot of Torah
38.50: When the wind settles, the reed yet stands upright in its place.

10.1: So too you, with what shall I bless you?
10.2: If in Torah, behold (you already have) Torah. If with wealth, behold (you already have) wealth. If with sons, behold (you already have) sons.
10.4: May it be (God's) will that those who issue from you will be like you."

13.43: "What does it mean, 'If the iron be blunt, then it is not damaged on the surface?' If you have seen a sky as blunt as iron, [shut up] from giving dew and rain, it is because of the deeds of the generation, that they secretly damage [society], as it says, 'it is not damaged on the surface.'
13.24: 'The rains do not stop, except for when there is arrogance, as it says, 'And the showers have been stopped, and the latter rains did not take place, for you had the forehead of a harlot {and refused to be ashamed}.'"
13.25: Rav Sela also said, "Rav Himnuna said,
13.26: 'Every man who is arrogant, in time will be caught up in sin, as it says (of the arrogant): 'And you had the forehead of a harlot.'"
13.20: "Because of the things that I commanded you in the days of the sun, which you did not do, the days of snow in the rainy season will be stolen from you."
13.21: Rav Shimon the son of Pazi said,
13.22: "The rains do not stop, except because of the tellers of slander, as it says, 'The north wind births rain, and angry faces (birth) private language.'"
13.46: "If you have seen a student... {continued next daf}
13.44: "How do they fix it? They should increase in mercy, as is says (in the continuation of the last verse), 'Then one should increase strength, and the direction of wisdom is profitable'. If they had acted in a proper manner originally [then they would not need mercy]."
13.28: "It is known that he (the arrogant one) is already caught up in sin, as it says, 'You had [the forehead of a harlot],' and not 'You will have.'"
13.29: Rabba the son of Rav Huna said,
13.40: How do we fix [the problem of insufficient rain and robbery]? Increase in prayer,
13.41: As it says, 'And he commanded about her regarding a touch' and their is no touching except for prayer, as it says, 'And you, do not pray on behalf of this people, and do not come into contact with me."
13.3: Rabbi Chama the son of Chanina said,
13.5: 'I have created them,' it did not say, but rather, 'I have created it [indicating that rain and the  whole world are a singular creation].'"
13.4: "The day of rain is as great as the day of the creation of heaven and earth, as it says, 'Heavens, drop down from above, and let the sky pour forth righteousness; let the earth open and flower salvation, and righteousness will grow along with it- I am G-d, I have created it.'
13.7: "The day of rain is so great that even salvation increases and grows on it (the day), as it says, 'Let the earth open and flower salvation.'"
13.39: "The rain does not stop, except for when there is the sin of robbery, like it says, 'Because of palms, light was covered,' which means that because of the sin of palms, the light was covered. There is no such term as palms except for armed robbery/violence, as it says, 'And from the violence in their palms'. There is no light, except for rain, as it says, 'a cloud will scatter its light.
13.17: "The rains do not stop, except for when there is a nullification of priestly gifts and tithes, as it says, 'Aridity, and also heat, steal from the days of snow.'"
13.19: It was taught in the academy in Rabbi Yishmael,
13.31: Rav Nachman the son of Yitzchak said,
13.30: "Every person who is arrogant may be called an evildoer, as it says, 'The arrogant man [can be called] an evildoer in his face.'"
13.37: Even in the time that the sky is made clear to bring dew and rain, a spirit passesand purifies them.
13.36: "Clear in the Heavens:" it was taught at the school of Rabbi Yishmael,
13.35: Rav Yosef quoted from the following, "'And now they shall see no clear light in the heavens, but a spirit shall pass and purify them,' and there is no such term as light except for Torah, as it says, 'For a candle is the commandment, and the Torah is a light.'
13.34: "The rain does not stop, except for when there is a nullification of Torah [study], as it says, 'with laziness shall the beams be injured" . Because of the laziness in Israel, that they didn't study Torah, the enemies of the Holy One, Blessed be He (euphemism for Israel), were injured, and there is such term as injury except for poverty, as it says, 'if he be poorer than his worth,' and there is no such term as beams except for the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it says, 'he who chills with water his higher dwelling.'"
13.32: "You are allowed to hate him [the arrogant one], as it says, 'and the arrogant of face shall change.' Do not read 'shall change (Yeshuneh),' but 'shall be hated (Yisanei).'"

12.42: "I have learned a lot from my teachers, and from my friends more than from my teachers; but from my students more than all of them."
12.48: If a student is worthy  "let your wellsprings spread forth (Proverbs 5:16)", and if not, "let them be yours alone (Proverbs 5:17)".
12.60: "Does your father put his wine in a earthenware container?"
12.64: "You who are important [people] should place it in vessels of gold and silver."
12.66: He had the wine placed in vessels of gold and silver and it soured.
12.24: '[About] that which is written (Deuteronomy 20:19), "as man is a tree of the field," and is man a tree of the field?
12.25: But rather because it is written (Deuteronomy 20:19), "as from it you shall eat and you shall not cut it down," and it is written (Deuteronomy 20:20), "it will you destroy and cut down."
12.27: If he is a proper Torah scholar, "from him shall you 'eat'  and you shall not cut him down"; and if not, "him will you destroy and cut down."'"
12.20: "My heart is faint and I can not."
12.21: "Let the master say a homiletical teaching (aggada)."
12.47: It is written "let your wellsprings spread forth (Proverbs 5:16)", and it is also written "let them be yours alone (Proverbs 5:17)".
12.44: It is written "toward the thirsty bring water (Isaiah 21:14)", and it is also written "woe, all that are thirsty go to water (Isaiah 55:1)".
12.45: If a student is worthy "toward the thirsty bring water" and if not "woe, all that are thirsty go to water."
12.29: "What is [the meaning of] what is written (Proverbs 27:17), 'Iron sharpens iron?' To say to you
12.40: [that] just as [in the case of] wood, a small [piece of] wood kindles the large [one]; so too small Torah scholars sharpen the great ones."
12.41: And this is that which Rabbi Chanina said,
12.5: “The day when rain falls is as great as the day when the Torah was given, as it is said [in Deuteronomy 32:2], ‘Let my teaching drop as the rain.’ When Moses said “teaching,” he meant Torah, as it is said of the Torah [in Proverbs 4:2] ‘For I give you sound teaching; do not abandon my Torah.’”
12.7: “The day when rain falls is as great as the day when the Torah was given, as it is said [in Deuteronomy 32:2], ‘My teaching shall drop like rain.’ When Moses said “teaching,” he meant Torah, as it is said of the Torah [in Proverbs 4:2] ‘For I give you sound teaching; do not abandon my Torah.’”
12.9: "Greater than the day the Torah was given, for it says, 'My teaching shall drop like rain'. Who is made dependent on whom? You should say:
12.51: just as water descends from a high place to a low place, so to words of Torah endure only in someone whose mind is lowly.
12.39: "Why are words of Torah compared to wood (a tree), as it is said (Proverbs 3:18), 'It is a tree of life for them that hold on to it?' To say to you
12.65: She went and said this to her father.
12.75: "Just like what she said to me, I said to her."
12.72: They had him called. [Caesar] said to him,
12.58: "Can glorious wisdom be [encased] in an ugly vessel?"
12.10: The small one (My teaching) is made dependent on the great (rain)."
12.13: If a scholar is proper, he is like dew. If not, drop him like rain."
12.12: "It is written , 'My teaching shall drop like rain,' and it is written, 'My sayings shall descend like dew.'
12.15: "Whoever is involved in Torah [study] for its own sake, it becomes a potion of life for him, as it says (Proverbs 3:18): 'It is a tree of life for them that hold on to it.' And it says (Proverbs 3:8), 'It shall be health to thy navel.' And it says (Proverbs 8:35), 'For those who find me, find life.'
12.14: It was taught in a bareita: Rabbi Benaah says,
12.17: Said Rabbi Yirmiya to Rabbi Zeira,
12.16: And whoever is involved in Torah [study] not for its own sake, it becomes a potion of death for him, as it says, 'My teaching shall fall like rain,' and falling only means killing, as it says, 'and they shall break [drop] the heifer’s neck there in the valley.'"
12.30: [that] just as [in the case of] iron, one sharpens its fellow; so too two Torah scholars sharpen each other in [matters of] Halacha (law)."
12.37: 'The princes of Tsoan have become foolish, [etc.] and they have misled Egypt' (Isaiah 19:13).
12.36: it is written here, 'and they will become foolish,' and it is written there (Numbers 12:11), 'that we have become foolish and that we have sinned'; and if you want, I will say from here:
12.35: "What is [the meaning of] what is written (Jeremiah 50:36), 'A sword upon the impostors (badim) and they will become foolish?' A sword on the haters of the Torah scholars that are involved one by one (bad bevad) in Torah [study]. And not only that, but they will become foolish; as it is said, 'and they will become foolish.' And not only that, but they sin -
12.34: And this is that which Rabbi Yossi bar Chanina said,
12.33: [that] just as [in the case of] fire, it does not kindle by itself; so too words of Torah do not survive by oneself.
12.32: "Why are words of Torah compared to fire, as it is said (Jeremiah 23:29), '"Are thus not My words like fire," spoke the Lord?' To say to you
12.57: It is as the daughter of Caesar said to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Channinah,
12.50: "Why are words of Torah likened to water, as it is written "woe, all that are thirsty go to water (Isaiah 55:1)"? To say to you

59.43: "'from us' - and not from our sons."
59.49: "It is the day that Hoshea ben Elah cancelled the sentries that Yeravaam ben Navat placed upon the roads, that Israel should not go to pilgrimage, and said,
59.25: "Rabbi Yehuda conceded to the sages concerning one who is not able, and the sages conceded to Rabbi Yehuda concerning one who is able."
59.27: What is between them is [the obligation to turn over] other beds [besides the one he uses].
59.21: 'According to your words, what will be with pregnant women and nursing women?'
59.23: 'Even I did not say, except concerning  one who is able [to fast].'"
59.47: "Until those dying in the desert ceased, there was no speech [of God] with Moshe, as it is stated (Deuteronomy 2:16-17), 'And it was when all of the men of war finished dying [...] And the Lord spoke to me' - to me was the speech [once again]."
59.44: Rabbah bar bar Chanah (said that) Rabbi Yochanan said,
59.45: "It is the day, that those dying in the desert ceased [dying]."
59.29: "When they said to turn over the bed, not only his bed does he turn over, but rather all of the beds does he turn over."
59.40: "It is the day that the tribe of Binyamin was allowed to come [into] the congregation [in marriage], as it is stated (Judges 21:1), 'And the men of Israel swore at Mitspeh, saying, "Not a man of us will give his daughter to Binyamin for a wife."'"
59.0: between the furnace and the oven and eat, and drink a pitcher of water upon [the dry bread] and he would be similar to someone whose dead was laying in front of him."
59.2: "In a place where they were accustomed to do work on the Ninth of Av, they may do [it]; in a place where they were not accustomed to do work, they may not do [it]; and in all places, Torah scholars refrain.
59.5: It was also taught thusly, "Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel says,
59.4: 'Really, every person should make himself be like a Torah scholar.'"
59.6: 'Really, a person should make himself be like a Torah scholar so that he fasts.'"
59.9: 'Anyone who eats and drinks on the Ninth of Av is as if he eats and drinks on Yom Kippur.'
59.39: Rav Yosef said that Rav Nachman said,
59.38: What is [this] expounded [from]? "This is the matter that the Lord commanded to the daughters of Tselophad, etc." (Numbers 36:6) - this matter will only be practiced for this generation.
59.11: 'Anyone who does work on the Ninth of Av does not ever see a sign of blessing.'
59.13: 'Anyone who does work on the Ninth of Av and does not mourn over Jerusalem will not see its rejoicing, as it is stated (Isaiah 66:10), "Rejoice with Jerusalem and be glad with her, all who love her; be gleeful with glee, all who mourn over her."'
59.15: 'Anyone who mourns over Jerusalem will merit to see her rejoicing; and who does not mourn over Jerusalem will not see her rejoicing.'"
59.17: "Anyone who eats meat and drinks wine on the Ninth of Av, about him the verse states (Ezekiel 32:27), 'and whose iniquities were upon their bones.'"
59.18: Rabbi Yehuda obligates turning over the bed and the sages did not concede to him:
59.31: "The law is like our teacher: 'and the sages did not concede to him' - at all."
59.37: "It is the day that the tribes were permitted to come one into another [in marriage]."
59.36: Rav Yehuda said that Shmuel said,
59.35: but the Fifteenth of Av, what is [its significance]?
59.34: It is fine with Yom Kippur, since it has forgiveness and pardoning upon it - it is the day upon which the second set of tablets were given;
59.33: "Never were there days as good for Israel as the Fifteenth of Av and Yom Kippur":

58.56: Rav Chinna bar Kahane said in the name of Shmuel,
58.54: "A mourner may eat cured meat and drink wine from its pressing vat."
58.61: "Frothing wine does not have [the possibility of the prohibition] of uncovered [wine].
58.62: And how much is its frothing? Three days."
58.63: Rav Yehuda said that Rav said,
58.64: "Such was the custom of Rabbi Yehuda beRebbi Ilaaye:
58.52: He should not eat meat or drink wine:
58.65: On the eve of the Ninth of Av, they would bring him dry bread with salt and he would sit
58.59: All the time it is frothing.
58.58: "And wine from its pressing vat" - until when [is it still considered form the vat]?
58.55: "Cured meat" - until when [is it considered fresh meat even though it is being cured]?
58.57: "All the time it is (it is not) [still] like the peace offerings."

17.1: The next day, when they took leave of him (Rav Papa told them:
17.0: They read the following verse in his dream; "And I have removed the three shepherds"(Zecharia.11:8)(implying that the three rabbis were about to be removed from the world).
17.3: Rav Shimi bar Ashi used to attend (the classes) of Rav Papa. He would ask him many questions (alternatively, point out difficulties).
17.5: "May the Merciful One save me from the humiliation of Rav Shimi”.
17.4: One day, (Rav Shimi) saw (Rav Papa) falling on his face, He heard him saying,
17.6: He (Shimi) took a vow of silence and questioned him no more.

16.56: When Rava passed away, they came to the classes held by Rav Papa.
16.42: Aaron died and the clouds of glory disappeared as it is written (Numbers 21:1), "And the Canaanite King of Arad heard."  What did he hear?  He heard that Aaron had died and the clouds of glory had disappeared and he thought permission had been  given him to war against Israel.
16.40: the well because of the merit of Miriam, the pillar of cloud because of the merit of Aaron and the manna because of the merit of Moses.
16.41: Miriam died and the well disappeared, as it is said (Numbers 20:1) "And Miriam died there." And it is written afterward and there was no water for the community and it returned because of the merit of both of them.
16.38: And three good gifts were given into their hands and these are them
16.36: Three good leaders stood for Israel and these are them
16.55: .Rav Huna bar Manoach,Rav Shmuel bar Idi and Rav Chiya from Vatanya would regularly attend the classes held by Rava.
16.57: Whenever he imparted a teaching that did not seem logical to them, they would signal this to each other.

57.1: "Therefore, an Israelite who has a court case in a gentile court should avoid it in Av, for [then] his luck is bad, and find time in Adar, for [then] his luck is good."
57.3: "These are palm trees and flax utensils."
57.2: "To give you a future and hope (Jeremiah 29:11)"- Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rav Shmuel the son of Shilat said in the name of Rav,
57.4: "And he said, 'The smell of my son is like that of a field which G-d has blessed (Genesis 27:27)"- Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rav Shmuel the son of Shilat said in the name of Rav,
57.6: (Mishnah:) During the week that the Ninth of Av falls on, it is forbidden to have a haircut and to launder-
57.9: "Even to launder and leave [the garment is forbidden].
57.8: "They only taught [this rule] about laundering to wear, but to launder and put down [the garment, without wearing it,] is permissible. Rabbi Sheishet said,

30.0: "Our brothers, it is not sackcloth and fasting (that) cause (God to forgive sins).  Rather, repentance and good deeds cause (God to forgive).  Thus we find with the people of Nineveh, as it was not said about them: 'And God saw their sackcloth and fasting,' but rather, 'And God Saw their deeds, for they had turned from their evil way' (Jonah 3:10).

37.38: At a time when its rains are plentiful, to what is it similar? To a man who is kneading clay: If he he has much water, the water does not finish and the clay is properly kneaded; if he has little water, the water finishes and the clay is not properly kneaded.
37.31: “From the day that the Temple was destroyed, the rains have become shriveled for the world. There is a year when the rains are plentiful and there is a year when the rains are sparse.
37.30: It was taught, RabbI Elazar ben Parta said,
37.36: A year when the rains are sparse, to what is it similar? To a servant whose master gives him his provisions a little at a time. It comes out that what the mill grinds from the kor, it grinds from the kav, and it comes out that what the dough consumes from the kor it consumes from the kav.”
37.35: A year when the rains are plentiful, to what is it similar? To a servant whose master gives him his provisions at one time. It comes out that the mill grinds from the kor (a bulk quantity) what it grinds from the kav (a small quantity), and it comes out that the dough consumes from the kor what it consumes from the kav.
37.34: A year when the rains don’t fall in their time, to what is it similar? To a servant whose master gives him his provisions on the eve of the Shabbat. It comes out that the dough is baked not as it should be and eaten not as it should be.
37.33: A year when the rains fall in their time, to what is it similar? To a servant whose master gives him his provisions on Sunday. It comes out that the dough is baked as it is should be and eaten as it should be.
37.32: There is a year when the rains fall in their time and there is a year when the rains don’t fall in their time.
